title: How many earthquakes of magnitude 5 or stronger will occur worldwide in October 2017?
preds: i'm showing 98 earthquakes... 5 more would put it in bucket #2... very close question... following @Khalid

93 M5+ earthquakes in October up to and including the 30th. It would take ten on the 31st to reach 103. However, there have been five earthquakes already in the first few hours of the 31st! As @Gibson surmised, there have been three aftershocks in New Caledonia following an M6.8 quake there. Could there be five more worldwide before midnight?
back down a bit. We're at 95 with (by my count) 5 or so hours to go. but a couple of hours ago, there was a fairly large (M6.8) earthquake which could have aftershocks...
Updating for 1 day remaining and 92 quakes to date.
91 as of this morning with 2 days (including today) to go...
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

91 in the month so far, up to and including 29 October. Rolling 31 day total is 100. The balance is tilting towards the lowest option once more, with just one such quake yesterday, after 6 the day before. There will have to be at least 12 in the last two days of October to reach the 103-142 option.
Geeze, 6 earthquakes yesterday just to make it all very close. @Raisinville - KT is right
faq would suggest that the question ends 12:59 a.m. pacific time oct 31
90 earthquakes in October up to and including the 28th. The rolling 31 day total is now 103. 13 more in the final three days will hit 103 for the month!

As KT Tunstall points out: 
"the earth will turn below you.....the pressures building, and something has to give....
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=PUi6FgVdepY
Updating for 3 days remaining and 83 quakes to date.
82 earthquakes of Magnitude 5 and above up to and including 27 October. Only one on the 27th, none on the 26th. They will have to average 5 per day from now on to reach 102 by the end of the month.
No quakes, should cause larger quakes, increased activity later.....but when?

I am getting a little uncomfortable with the data source I am using (the one provided). 1) I got on the website this morning and the Oct figure went from 80 to 79. It appears one taken away from Oct. 25th. 2) Now I get on the site and it has gone back up to 80, but none added to Oct 25th or later. 3) All of a suden no quakes 5.0 or higher in the past nearly 48 hours. All of this may be fine, but gives me reason for concern. All of that said, I can only forecast on the data I have and I have no alternative data source.

79?! Oh no! The number is going down...
Someone erased one earthquake on the 16th of October. What a mysterious crime...

The USGS website is showing only 79 earthquakes in October, whereas yesterday it showed 80. Assuming they corrected an error and that also that there was no earthquake on 26 October, the "Less than 103" option has become much more likely, especially as the rolling 31 day total (26 September to 26 October) is shown as 99, the first time it has dropped below 103 this month. EDIT - the count to date for October is back up to 80, and the rolling 31 day total to 100.
As of yesterday, only 80. On track to be less than 103 However, a major earthquake could set off many aftershocks, and possibly foreshocks, >5.0. So there still is a possibility of over 103.

There have been an average of 140/month over the past year, but only 101 in the past 30 days. 151 in September. October to date may not be complete yet. Earthquakes follow the Gutenberg-Richter relation which means the number of earthquakes > M5 is approximately constant over time.
Shifting lower since there haven't been many earthquakes this month.
Based on MTD I think we close full month between 99 and 104. Simply put, 2/3 of the totals in that range are below 103.

3 on the 25th.
Data uses UTC, giving small break on the closing time.
Second after shock near yesterday's 6.7 quake.

Wow, we've been averaging almost exactly the 10-year daily average which would put us exactly at 103 on October 31st.....certainly not obvious conclusion at this point!   Since the daily earthquake occurrence is a left skewed distribution I will maintain my bias towards <103 for the month.
There was a large 6.7 earthquake in Indonesia yesterday which could induce above average tremors in that locale but they are frequently below M5.0+

77 earthquakes of Magnitude 5+ in October up to and including the 24th. Extrapolating the daily average to 31 days gets to between 99 and 100, while the rolling 31 day total from 24th September to 24th October has come down to 106.

Full month pace keeps inching up.
If last seven days pace keeps up through the 31st, together with MTD rate of 77, we will hit 105. I think it’s even odds now and trending towards >103.
No after shocks (so far) after today's 6.4 quake off of Indonesia.

I love this question. I am checking how many earthquakes there have been multiple times a day. It clearly looks like it is down to two bins with less than a week left on the clock. Only one so far today and we are midway through the day. I need to ajust my forecast lower.

74 earthquakes in October upto and including the 23rd. Extrapolating the daily average to 31 days gets just about 100.
The rolling 31 day total from 23rd September to 23rd October is 109.

3 quakes clustered off S Africa yesterday.
As long as the SE Asia and Australian areas remain quiet.....

MTD pace still just 98.
However, the pace is picking up.
Average of 4.57 earthquakes per day last 7 days.
73 MTD as of right now, plus this faster pace the rest of the month, puts us at 109.56.
Adjusting my forecast.
Derived from the Poisson distribution and an average daily rate of about 4.6, taking into account earthquakes so far this month.
Inexcusable math error in my last forecast. Readjusting. Thanks again @CubsWin .

69 through the 22nd, which is 3.14 per day. 3 per day from now through the 31st puts us at 102, whereas 3.14 per day puts us over 103.
Feels like 103 or more is a VERY strong possibility now. Adjusting my forecast.

69 earthquakes of Magnitude 5 and above in October up to and including the 22nd. 107 such earthquakes in the last 31 days, from 22Sep to 22 Oct. Just 9 days left. Is the month-end total going to be below 103 or not? It's beginning to look as though it may, against my expectations when this question opened.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

We’ve been running at a pace of about three earthquakes per day of this magnitude since the start of the month. To reach 103 for October that pace would only have to increase to 4 per day, which would not at all be outside the norm. In fact, given the monthly average YTD (146 per month = 4.8 per day) even THAT would be below average. Forecasting 60/40 in favor of less than 103 for now based on MTD average, but it is easy to see how the pace could pick up and the 103 threshold could be reached. One good rash of 5.0 or stronger quakes and I’ll adjust the other direction.

Base rate for the month ~>110
Rarely below 100.
Fewer than average this month so far.
Earthquakes are basically a random number generator, with major earthquakes generating a flurry of aftershocks, some >magnitude 5. I'm choosing 30% below and 70% above 100 with only 5% above 142,  on the basis of the base rate and given that the month so far is below the base rate. Will watch the random number generator carefully and adjust if needed.
There's only been 66 so far this month.

Sources I found helpful in learning about earthquake frequency probabilities:
Ch5 of Nate Silver's book on forecasting, The Signal and the Noise 
How frequent are earthquakes? - British Geological Survey pdf As of 21 October, there had been 62 earthquakes of magnitude 5 or above.
To stay in the <103 range there would need to be 40 or fewer in the 10 full days remaining.
Using the Poisson approach outlined in the BGS article:
P(no 5+ earthquakes in 10 days <= 40) = c.52%
So a 52% probability of finishing the month in the <103 range.
To breach the next threshold (>142) we would need 81 in the next 10 days. P(no earthquakes >= 81) is vanishingly small. Therefore, the whole remaining 48% probability of exceeding 103 is allocated to the next range up (103 - 142 inclusive). Interesting to compare this with the probabilities that the Poisson approach would have given at the start of the month: P(no earthquakes < 103) would have been more like 2%, P(103 - 142 inclusive) more like 92% and the next range up around 6%.
Worth revisiting each day till the question closes...

October 2016: 106
Average Per Month L6M: 149
Last 30 days: 101
Last 31 days: 111
MTD Daily Avg: 3.05 (94.55 full month pace)

There's been 59 as of 10/19, for an average of a smidgen more than 3 a day.
At that rate, there will be 100 in October.

Pace of earthquakes has picked up in the last week. But must pick up even more to reach 103 for the month. Still more likely to hit under that threshold in my opinion. Barring a very large quake that brings on significant aftershocks, that is.

58 earthquakes in the first 19 days of October, which is less than the average needed to reach 103 by the 31st.  On the other hand, there have been 114 earthquakes of Magnitude 5 and above in the last 31 days (19 Sep to 19 Oct). I intend to keep an eye on that rolling 31 day total from now on.

56 quakes by 10/19
Likelihood of > 176 plummeting
Still need 7+ per day to get 142
Adjusting to account for the 56 current quakes as we're just over 19.5 days into the period. Need 47 more in the next 11.5 days to get into the 103-142 range.
Dropping lower because this doesn't seem like a big earthquake month.
Passage of time. Four statistical snapshots have all shown a pace on track for below 103.

Lol: always fun to be on a fool's errand:
"FICTION: We can predict earthquakes.
There is no scientifically plausible way of predicting the occurrence of a particular earthquake. The USGS can and does make statements about earthquake rates, describing the places most likely to produce earthquakes in the long term. It is important to note that prediction, as people expect it, requires predicting the magnitude, timing, and location of the future earthquake, which is not currently possible. The USGS and other science organizations are working to better understand earthquakes in the hope of eventually being able to predict the size, location and time that an earthquake will happen. The USGS does produce aftershock forecasts that give the probability and expected number of aftershocks in the region following large earthquakes."
https://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/topics/megaqk_facts_fantasy.php
edit: it goes on...
FACT: The U.S. Geological Survey is conducting research to better forecast the effects of potentially damaging earthquakes throughout the United States and mitigate their effects.
Basic and applied scientific research is being carried out to predict the types of ground shaking expected from future large earthquakes based upon the probabilities (or likelihoods) of those earthquakes occurring, the physics of the earthquake source, the propagation of seismic waves through the Earth’s crust and local site effects. Together with rupture scenarios for specific faults, these hazard assessments are essential for multiple applications, including: Probabilistic seismic hazard assessments such as the National Seismic Hazard Map that underlie seismic provisions of building and other regulatory codes; as well as detailed urban seismic hazard maps that include the effects of rupture directivity, 3D basin response and soil nonlinearity. These urban hazard maps will be included in code updates for selected regions.
Development of credible earthquake scenarios for specific faults with synthetic ground-motion time histories for evaluating current engineering design practice, improving building codes and for emergency planning and public education.
Other uses of these hazard products include: 1) site-specific designs and retrofits of critical and major facilities such as bridges, hospitals, nuclear power reactors, dams and tall buildings, 2) modeling damage patterns and damage to specific structures after earthquakes, 3) assessing secondary earthquake hazards such as liquefaction and landslides and 4) computing actuarially sound earthquake insurance premiums.
I am guessing a moderate amount.

Changed my approach completely on this question in the past couple days. I started out looking at average quakes > 5.0 per day for a long period of time 27 years. However, the reason there have been so few MTD has been there have been no large earthquakes (call that >7.0) Oct or late-Sep. Large quakes trigger many aftershocks > 5.0. For instance, the 8.1 quake in Mexico on 9-8-17 triggered 22 after-shocks by my counting within a small radius of the original larger quake in a three day period. So, until a large quake occurs, I am skewing me forecast much lower. However, if one does occur, my estimate will go up rapidly.
Earthquakes have been trending down typically less than 80 4+ magnitude in any given week.  Only 48 MTD so though I discount less than 103 trends make it more likely than the upper bound.

the below comes with the caveat that i may have calculated the instances of zero- and one-earthquake-per-day wrong (i do not know much of anything about using data)... but playing around with a few thousand earthquake reports from 2002-2011 seemed to indicate that about 95% of the time, there are fewer than 12 earthquakes per day. it looks like a lognormal distribution. There's a 75% chance you won't see 10 earthquakes in a day given 15 days; a 50% chance you won't see 9 in a day given 15 days, etc.  However the tail is very long so a given instance in say the top 2% of quakeprone days could blow up any given forecast.  Eyeballing all the quakes per day though time, the data had a pattern that was kind of like steam or lava bubbling in some wind that blew along the x axis from past to future. I wish I knew how to do markov type stuff... probably matters where you are in the present in making a short term prediction more than looking at random samples of months over a large set. nonscientific intuition about the earth's plates is the # of quakes probably tend to accelerate then fall off abruptly; most of the time not much happens, but the extreme events are even more extreme than they are rare. i have no idea how to predict what will happen with this one.

Number of quakes over the past twenty years per month: (4%, 63%, 22%, 11%, 0%) is base rate.  The average number for past twenty years is 138.   The average number is 138 during the same time frame.  Regression puts 2017 at ~ 152 w/ .16 r2.  September there were 143.  with 76 at half way point.  Currently less than half at halfway point.  See no reason to change rates.

Given my daily average and 42 earthquakes to date in October:
We need 4 per day to get 103 (slightly below average daily)
We need 6.7 per day to get >142
We need 8.9 per day to get >176
We need 11.5 per day to get >214 These are all within 1 standard deviation of the daily average, assume a left-skewed distribution.  103-42 is still most likely.

After 15 days in October, there have been just 41 earthquakes of magnitude 5.0 and above. averaging less than 3 per day. 
In the next 16 days, there would have to be more than 61 to reach the 103-142 bracket, and more than 102 to reach 142-176. I'm going to discount the higher two options now, as there would have to be an average of more than 8 per day to reach 176-214, and more than 11 per day to get to 215.
Nature doesn't follow averages, but this is as good a strategy as any.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
A planet sized random number generator! Unless I'm wrong, for example if a 9+ event might trigger many aftershocks, perhaps over 5.
USGS (https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/search/) lists 41 quakes magnitude 5+ 01-Oct through 14-Oct. So revising my forecast down.
Making a big adjustment in expectations as the first half of the month continues to be relatively quiet versus long term averages.

41 just now. 41/(14/31)=~91; on the other hand, there were 4 today and an avg of 4 or so more per day for the rest of the month would do it (105+). no idea whether there's seasonality to earthquakes of 5+magnitude but for the last several octobers there's been a decline in their number (probably just random chance... the trend certainly doesn't stretch back forever).

The number of earthquakes (5+) to date for Oct 2017 is 37.  September 2017 was 143, but had 67 earthquakes of magnitude 5 (or more) in the first 13 days of the month.  October 2016 had 106 earthquakes of magnitude 5 (or more), of which, 43 occurred in the first 13 days. Therefore we should be around 100 to 113.
Average daily rate over past 27 years is 4.56. MTD 37 quakes. I am using a pretty big standard deviation around the expected daily rate to arrive at my numbers.

Average per month over last 10 years = 157
2017 Average month over 9 months = 129
October quakes so far = 36 which extrapolated comes to 93 But since one cannot possibly predict when earthquakes will hit, this is just dart throwing numbers so...

Following is from USGS Earthquake catalouge mag5+ events from 10/2010 - present.
https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/search/ Avg. monthly EQ's = 150
SD. monthly EQs = 73
Avg. Daily EQs = 5 
Std dev. daily EQs = 7.3 Very few months since 2014 with less than 103, very few with more than 176 (3).
36 mag5+ events thus far this October 2017.   Tectonic plates move constantly but as stress builds up at plate boundaries the plates fail elastically in abrupt "cycles".  In other words there tend to be relative peaks and troughs of activity as stress builds up, and then rocks fail and the system resets.  However, since the scope is global - these peaks and troughs should even out over time, maybe annually.  September was an "average" month towards the end of an increasing trend in monthly events beginning in June.  Standard deviations at the monthly and daily level are large, so predictability seems low without knowing more.
Nearly halfway through the month we have only had 36 earthquakes more than 5.0 so at this rate I'm expecting to see less than 103 this month.
Last year had roughly 1600 quakes fitting the 5+ scale.
thank you for wikipedia - but 0 under 103 ?

10 earthquakes in the first five days of October 2017, which would give us only 62 for the whole month if extrapolated.  With earthquakes, however, one can't extrapolate! All the same, it's fun playing with these numbers. @dsarin has tabulated daily earthquakes in October starting from 2013, so if one makes the dubious assumption that there is some seasonal association between calendar months and earthquakes, the average number of earthquakes in the last four Octobers has been 116 (lower than the average of 136 for the full four years, and giving some support to the simplistic approach of the first para above). Assuming an association, then the average daily number of earthquakes  in October from 2013 to 05 Oct 2017 comes to approximately 3.67 with a standard deviation of 2.09, which leads to the revised probabilities above. The big difference compared to the calculation for all months is that the probability of less than 103 has increased from 19% to 43%.  I don't really believe this, but I don't see any harm in holding this forecast for a few days till we get more data from the current month. The number of earthquakes per day ranged from 0 to 15, so the calculation could change drastically within days.
Through the first 5.5 days only 11 quakes of 5.0 or more. Daily average over the past 17 years is 4.86, making the expected October figure 135. That is if I have the calculation and approach correct.

There is only nothing that can predict them today.

with a slight adjustment upwards for the increased seismic activity that seems to be associated with fracking. @Jtrommel, you might find this a fun question!

Earthquake (and other weather)  tracking by tracking # of  bright lights attributed to UFO sightings - about half as many in 2017 compared to peak year, 2016. The theory goes what looks like lights in the sky, are lightwaves from heat generated by rocks in an earthquake-immanent zone.
http://www.nuforc.org/webreports/ndxevent.html

Based on empirical distribution of the rolling 26 day distribution. + There are already 10 events on the first 5 days of Oct.

Recalculating based on average and standard deviation of the totals in each of the last 57 complete months - approximately 136 and 38. This spreads the probabilities more than just taking the proportions in each bin.

From 2000-2016 the average daily rate of earthquakes 5.0 & higher was 4.86 per day. With 31 days in October, this would put the expected number at 150.66. However, month to date, there have been only 9 earthquakes of this size, a slow start. Assuming the next 26.5 days in October revert to the mean, the expected number would be 137.85. Unfortunately, I do not have much information on variation of the daily statistics, just the average daily figure.

Thanks to @dsarin, @shivadiva, @achohen, @dada for links to data. Since January 2013 (57 complete months), there have been 5 months with less than 103 earthquakes, 3 with earthquakes  between 176 and 214 , and three with more than 214. There have been 34 months with between 103 and 142 earthquakes, and 12 with earthquakes between 143 and 175. The range over this period has been from 92 to 287 per month. Between the years 2005 to 2011 the frequency of earthquakes was rather higher, but unless the October figures show a significant increase I'll stay with the more recent years.

October 19 is the Great Shakeout ! Largest one in history ! 
https://www.shakeout.org/ Leaning towards the higher part of the scale because of the link between earthquakes and tropical cyclones, and climate change
https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/12/111208121016.htm https://www.carbonbrief.org/can-climate-change-cause-earthquakes-we-look-at-the-science-and-the-spin

Well this is a fun guessing game. Looking at the monthly average of earthquakes going back to 2000 (link to the raw data I used in my calculations is below) the average monthly number is 148 but with some pretty wild swings. Also, in that same data set, Oklahoma looks like its trying to shake itself apart. Not relevant to anything just a fun fact, if you're not an Oklahoman that is. https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/browse/stats.php

According to USGS data there were 30,188 world wide 5 or stronger quakes 2000-2016 (average = 147 per month. There was an increase in yearly quakes between 2007 and 2011 (avg = 185/month) compared to 5 years before  (2002-2006; 134/month) and 5 years after (2012- 2016; 135/month). Through end of Sep there's been 1157 (avg=128/month in 2017). A small data set to be sure but it's a start.

Based on the Earthquake Catalog's past month of recordings. But seriously, this question is entirely dependent on chance, as science hasn't progressed sufficiently to accurately predict earthquakes.  With that, I'm always looking for new ways to ruin my Brier score, so why not take a crack at this!
137 in September, 120 in August, but I'm drawing blanks for earlier months. I'm making an initial forecast now, and will make a broader search tomorrow.
